Somewhere along the line we became myth-makers and story-tellers and religion is an outgrowth of that. I'm guessing we had social order well before we had religion to bind and distinguish us from the others tribes, and that order survives in spite of religion.  I agree that humanity will always be bigger than religion if for no other reason than it predates religion. If there is a divine image that we reflect, it must also be vindictive, judgemental, and self-centered since those qualities are reflected in equal measure.  Religions may have adopted and adapted ethics for their own purposes, but I can't help thinking that ethics (and social order), like everything else, evolved through millennia of trial-and-error.

Religions may "bind together" groups of people. But it appears largely as a form of tribalism, despite the various ethical adornments claimed. And those ethical adornments have presented little or no barrier to the perpetration of atrocities against various "others", from the St. Bartholomews Day Massacre to modern day Sunni moslems detonating themselves amongst a crowd of Shia.
Moreover organized religions have been mere accomplices to the crimes of the state - with a few rare exceptions.
Ethical norms can be propagated without necessitating belief in the irrational, and without inculcating blind obedience.
It would be nice if religion bound EVERYONE together, but instead it mostly just sets up "us" and "them" together.

The etymological derivation of the word "religion" is "to bind together". Religion presents a unified vision of society and mystery. It has enabled the single most pivotal human trait, co-operation. As individuals, we are relatively small and weak, but when we work together, we change the world we live on. This togetherness is the only thing that enabled us to survive. It is also responsible for all our moral values. Religion is an artifact of our evolution as a social species. Tenets come and go. Zoroaster and Zeus have fallen on hard times, but the laws they upheld enabled inclusion and productivity where conflict had denied civil society agriculture, trade and emigration. In the end, the spirit of humanity is bigger than any one religion. If we were made in the divine image, it must be a functional, conscious, reasoning, compassionate and creative image because the spirit which unites us has no image. Religion's essential teaching is that ethics enable survival.

A far more difficult fight is opposition to the renewed use of "girl" to refer to an adult woman, the continued denigration of women in films, activities that single out women as a primary focus. I'll go to a women's forum when men start going to men's forums. When is the last time a film had a female lead whose plot trajectory had nothing to do with a sexual relationship? Come 2016 we need to all insist that we have a female president. I've had enough of men running this country.

Your post exemplifies one of the problems that I have with the attitudes of many people toward religion--the belief that religion is necessary to "civilize" people and that without religion "relationships with the community would be much less dependable and honorable,"  and so on for the rest of your aunt's claims.  Don't you think it a bit insulting to claim that people need religion to be civilized?  To believe that caring about others requires a religious framework?  Yes, churches, or organized religions, if you will, facilitate carrying out work that benefits others in several different ways, for example, by teaching about serving others and by providing both a place where people come together to learn about what is needed and then to plan and join together in carrying out helpful actions.  OTOH, various secular organizations have done and are doing the same sorts of things.  And they do it without the intolerance and self-righteousness that all too often are part and parcel of religious organizations.  It would pay to remember that many of the Europeans who first came to the new world did so to escape religious persecution in their home countries--persecution that came not from the non-religious but from others who believed in a different religion.  Of course, once here most of them practiced the same sort of behavior towards those not of their beliefs.  There are many positive aspects to religion, but there are also many that are negative and harmful.
Which is why, I imagine, Texas (particularly East Texas which I am familiar with) is such a wonderful example of multicultural tolerance and respect for universal human rights.

When my grandparents immigrated to Texas from the Isle of Man, my grandmother found the closest religion to High Church Episcopalian that she could find in the tiny little East Texas town where they resided was the United Methodist Church.
While Methodism was not considered a righteous Protestant sect in the Church of England, my grandmother sent her children to Vacation Bible School every summer to give her children some exposure to Christian doctrine, even if flawed.
Years later, her daughter, my aunt, a high-school English teacher, would often say that she believed religious training and moral teaching civilized people, and that without it, relationships within the community would be much less dependable and honorable.
She believed people would behave in a cutthroat manner toward their fellows.
Concern for the less fortunate would slacken.
Thanks to the example church organizations gave, many organizations grew up around community needs, such as research to conquer diseases, caring for families in times of disaster, etc.
Of course, today, the rabid demands engendered in mega-churches doesn't seem to direct its energy toward community needs.
They appear to be much more ego-driven, less humble and less concerned with community needs, but rather focus on proselytizing activities.
Today, our mainstream churches are dwindling; we will find we will miss their excellent service and kindess to others someday.

Boy I miss attending a full blown Indian wedding.

I am quite aware that some people (the bride's family) often go into debt to put up a lavish show. And I can understand the criticism.

But then there are people with pots of money who are having a great time. I have not been to a former (only read about them), and attended a couple of the latter.

And holy mackerel are they great. The color, the music, the drink, the food! Grandmas and grandpas dancing, children dancing. Great singers, musicians and performers are invited, people write and recite poetry, women spend an evening wearing mehndi. People seem to let go and tend to burst forth. Everyone is dressed up and looks fantastic. I suspect there is plenty of drama too. Who cares; let the kill joys stay home. For those interested, Indian rum is pretty darned good.

No one I know is about to get married in India anytime soon. 'tis a pity.

Personally, some of the best weddings I have attended had under a 100 guests.  They were most memorable because the bride and groom decided to make it a 3 to 4 day festivity, in a central local, that allowed all guests to mingle with one another over breakfast, lunch and dinner.  The rest of the time was spent sightseeing.  There was no 11pm cutoff time.  I loathe it when the DJ reminds us of the last dance.

I think the main reason behind this opulence is the fact ' dad is paying for everything'. If the couple had to pay even a fraction of the costs most of the excess will vanish.
I am all for one spending all they can as they wish. I hope the bride and groom try keep some perspective and not get into to doing one up on the last wedding they have attended or heard about.
